paragraph.paragraph:
The Eiffel editor allows you to edit and manage multiple Eiffel
/20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *classes from within Visual Studio .NET.
The editor comes complete with a host of features common to Visual Studio .NET and other existing languages. For a full list of details of editor features, please see urlEditor Features.

The editor has two modes for editing:
Project associated editing
Standalone editing

project_editing Project associated editing:
This mode of editing refers to /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes opened and edited from an EiffelEnvision project. Opening Eiffel classes in this way extends the editor's feature set. You will have access to vcovrAutomaticStatementCompletion 0 intellisense and code browsing tools such as urlGo to Definition.

standalone_editing Standalone editing:
This mode of editing refers to /20_Language/10_Eiffel_NET/10_Conventions/index.xml classes *Eiffel classes opened from other projects, such as C# or VB.NET, through Windows Explorer or via the File, Open menu in Visual Studio .NET. When editing documents in this mode, a number of editor context items may be hidden or grayed out because of their dependency on an EiffelEnvision project. Documents opened using the project associated editing may actually be in standalone editing mode. This can happen when an EiffelEnvision project has no project-specific compiled information available to provide the services required by the editor.
